thread.title: Unbeaten Vikings look to stay perfect tonight in trip to rival McIntosh
thread.title_full: Unbeaten Vikings look to stay perfect tonight in trip to rival McIntosh

title: Unbeaten Vikings look to stay perfect tonight in trip to rival McIntosh
text:
Unbeaten Vikings look to stay perfect tonight in trip to rival McIntosh by Comments 
Northgate head coach Tommy Walburn knows there’s a lot of football left to be played heading into tonight’s short trip across the county line to face Region 4A- rival McIntosh. 
Out to a 5-0 record, Northgate is still off to its best start since going undefeated in the regular season and winning a region title in 2011 while con- trolling its own destiny. 
A week ago, Northgate faced its biggest challenge of the season, but passed the test with flying colors, beating Mundy’s Mill 34-7 to move to 2-0 in subregion play. 
The victory came with a little revenge after the Tigers kept Northgate out of the playoffs with wins the last two seasons. 
Like they have done all year, Northgate’s wing-T offense generated plenty of mileage, finishing with 351 total yards, including 335 on the ground. 
It’s defense allowed just 180 yards, including just 60 on the ground. 
Walburn admits he can feel a buzz around practice because of the team’s fast start. 
“It makes it easier to coach when you are having some success,” Walburn said. “The kids listen a little better because what you have told them is working, but you also have to guard against complacency.” 
That’s especially true against Friday night’s opponent. 
Despite owning a 7-4 series record against McIntosh, Walburn knows his team doesn’t always play its best football when the two schools meet. 
In fact, Northgate hasn’t won a football game in Peachtree City since 2004 in the first meeting between schools. 
“There is just something about that game,” he said. “I don’t know if it’s just because it’s such a big rivalry. It’s really a rivalry in all sports between our two schools. I know they get up for it, and so do we.” 
McIntosh brings a 2-3 record into the region contest, including last week’s 35-6 victory over Morrow, a team Northgate beat 56-0 two weeks ago. 
The Chiefs also beat Fayette County in a non-region game to open the season. 
“Every game is big from here on out,” Walburn said. 
The Vikings can point to the play of their running backs for the quick start. 
Ton Evans rushed for 167 yards and a touchdown in the victory against Mundy’s Mill and now has 703 yards and nine touchdowns. Fellow junior Kyle Cater had his best performance of the season after rushing for 112 yards and a touchdown despite losing the first fumble of the year by Northgate’s starting backfield. 
The bulldozing fullback has rushed for 335 yards and seven touchdowns while helping the Vikings convert 55-percent of third-down conversions this year. 
Sophomore quarterback Kyle McLaren only completed two passes last week, but one went for a touchdown. He also threw his first interception of the season. 
“I put that interception on myself,” Walburn said. “The positive thing to see was the way he balanced back from it. Sometimes we have to remind ourselves he is 15-years old.” 
McLaren has connected with five receivers this year, and showed a new wrinkle against Mundy’s Mill, hitting Evans out of the backfield twice, one of which on a short touchdown throw that capped off an impressive 62-yard drive in 59 seconds just before halftime for a 22-7 advantage. 
Defensively, Northgate’s three senior linebackers each dominated play. Clemson recruit James Skalski led the way with 15 tackles, including a sack and a forced fumble. Kyle Feldbauer had eight tackles and fellow senior Carson Storey had six tackles to go with an interception and a fumble recovery. 
Lineman Drew Latham, meanwhile, added seven tackles and forced a safety that pushed the Vikings to an early 9-0 lead. . 
Obvious comparisons are being made between this year’s Northgate team and the one from 2011 that went undefeated until the playoffs. 
“There are some similarities.” Walburn said. “We knew in 2010 we had some good seniors, but the bulk of our teams was coming back with some really good young players, and that is the same way with this team. In 2013 we were playing a lot of sophomores, and in 2014 we thought we were on the right track, but we had all those injuries. I think this team is a little bigger up front on both sides of the ball.” 
Walburn noted the play of a senior offensive line, as well as senior wingback Kamari Ray after last week’s game. Ray opened the scoring with a 4-yard run last week. 
After Friday’s game, Northgate heads into its bye week before resuming the season back at home against Forest Park for Homecoming on Oct. 16. 
“It is always good to get some time off,” Walburn said. “However, sometimes when everything is going so well, it can break up your momentum.” More
